question: Based on the provided evidence, answer the following question: A 45-year-old woman presents to the physician with a history of headache, palpitations, and episodic diaphoresis. She was diagnosed with hypertension in the past and is now regularly taking antihypertensive medication (amlodipine 10 mg once daily). She has had a diffuse thyroid swelling for the past 4 months. She complains of pain in the long bones of her arms and legs for the past 3 months. She is slightly built, appears thin, and is anxious and apprehensive. Her skin is moist and warm. Her weight is 45 kg (99.2 lb) and height is 146 cm (4 ft 7 in); BMI is 21.12 kg/m2. Her pulse is 116/min, the blood pressure is 196/102 mm Hg, the respiratory rate is 29/min, and the temperature is 37.2В°C (99.0В°F). Diffuse and firm thyromegaly is present. Her upper extremities exhibit fine tremors during an anxiety attack. The laboratory test results reveal elevated 24-hour urinary VMA and metanephrines. Serum epinephrine, calcitonin, and parathormone levels are also elevated. Hypercalcemia and hyperglycemia are also noted. What is the most likely diagnosis?. If there are multiple answers, separate them with commas. In your explanation, point out what is correct and incorrect in the evidence.

content.source_1: The constellation of catecholamine-mediated symptoms and biochemical abnormalities in a 45-year-old woman—headache, palpitations, episodic diaphoresis, tachycardia (pulse 116/min), and severe hypertension (blood pressure 196/102 mm Hg) despite amlodipine 10 mg once daily—together with elevated 24-hour urinary vanillylmandelic acid (VMA) and metanephrines, and increased serum epinephrine, is diagnostic of a catecholamine-producing tumor consistent with pheochromocytoma. Concomitant thyroid involvement is suggested by 4 months of diffuse thyroid swelling, diffuse and firm thyromegaly on examination, and elevated serum calcitonin, indicating parafollicular C-cell pathology consistent with medullary thyroid carcinoma. In addition, bone-related symptoms (pain in the long bones of the arms and legs for 3 months) with elevated parathormone and hypercalcemia support primary hyperparathyroidism, while hyperglycemia in the setting of catecholamine excess is a recognized metabolic accompaniment. The patient is slightly built, appears thin, and is anxious and apprehensive; her skin is moist and warm, and her respiratory rate is 29/min with a temperature of 37.2В°C (99.0В°F), and her anthropometrics include weight 45 kg (99.2 lb), height 146 cm (4 ft 7 in), and BMI 21.12 kg/m2. The triad of pheochromocytoma, medullary thyroid carcinoma, and primary hyperparathyroidism—as evidenced by the clinical presentation and laboratory profile—constitutes the syndromic diagnosis of Multiple Endocrine Neoplasia 2A.
content.source_2: This 45-year-old woman manifests a syndromic aggregation of endocrine neoplasms and hyperfunction: an adrenergic syndrome characterized by headache, palpitations, episodic diaphoresis, tachycardia (pulse 116/min), and marked hypertension (blood pressure 196/102 mm Hg) refractory to amlodipine 10 mg once daily, in association with elevated 24-hour urinary VMA and metanephrines and increased serum epinephrine, is consistent with a pheochromocytoma; a 4-month history of diffuse thyroid swelling with diffuse and firm thyromegaly and elevated serum calcitonin implicates parafollicular C-cell disease consistent with medullary thyroid carcinoma; and bone pain affecting the long bones of the arms and legs for 3 months with elevated parathormone and hypercalcemia indicates primary hyperparathyroidism. Hyperglycemia is also noted, and the patient’s phenotype includes slight build, thin appearance, anxiety and apprehension, moist and warm skin, fine tremors in the upper extremities during an anxiety attack, respiratory rate 29/min, temperature 37.2В°C (99.0В°F), weight 45 kg (99.2 lb), height 146 cm (4 ft 7 in), and BMI 21.12 kg/m2. This triadic pattern of pheochromocytoma, medullary thyroid carcinoma, and primary hyperparathyroidism, supported by the specific biochemical signatures and organ involvement, is diagnostic of Multiple Endocrine Neoplasia type 2A.
